reviewText:
This is actually a really fun game. I'm having more fun with it than I originally thought I would be.

Super 3-D Noah's Ark is a labyrinth FPS from the DOS era which used and upgraded Wolfenstein 3D's engine. It added a few cool things like MIDI support and texture-mapped floors and ceilings. This version on Steam has been repolished and ported over to modern operating systems, so now there's no need to use DOSBoX to emulate it!

The quality of this port is really good. The sound quality has been bumped up significantly, it can play in 1080p with true 16:9 aspect ratio (no stretching), the mouselook feels natural and it supports mods. This release also has achievements and trading cards, which is more than what most re-releases or remakes get.

In many ways I think this game is actually better than Wolfenstein 3D. The music is better for sure and there's more enemies scattered about, which leads to more action. The level design is smart. While the levels are maze-like, I have an easier time finding my way around and not being completely lost, like I did a lot with Wolfenstein's lack of color and texture variety. So nevermind the somewhat religious theme, as the game barely even touches upon the story.

The developer of this port is a core developer of ZDoom and ECWolf, and has some involvement with the development of Zandronum. If you play Doom, you likely have already used this guy's work before. The money spent on this game supports the development of the ECWolf engine (the engine this game uses) which will be receiving updates, like online multiplayer. If you take a peak in the forums, you'll understand why this developer is so cool and why he deserves your money. After all, it's just 5 bucks! Which is the same price as Wolfenstein 3D on Steam but without all the fancy upgrades.

If you were into Wolf3D or Ken's Labyrinth, you're gonna love this. Recommended.

reviewText:
9/10 Christians agree that Super 3D Noah's Ark is the most accurate video game adaptation of the story of Noah's arc.

----------------------------

Okay so, sarcastic reviews aside, this game is actually pretty fun. If you enjoy Wolfenstein 3D, then you’ll be satisfied with this. The game uses the same modification as the ECWolf mod for Wolfenstein, if you’re familiar with ECWolf it’s exactly the same.
For my review I wanted to compare Super 3D Noah’s Ark to Wolfenstein and what areas are better or worse.

-Theme-
If it wasn’t obvious, this game is a very family-friendly game. Rather than killing enemies you are feeding them to put them to sleep. This is in stark contrast to Wolf3D which was about dropping as many dudes as you encountered. So if the rather light-hearted and, let’s face it, silly nature of the game doesn’t hold a certain charm for you then you probably won’t enjoy it that much.

-Weapons-
Super 3D Noah’s Ark and Wolfenstein 3D are pretty similar in terms of weapons and how they function.  Hand feeding is the knife (that is, melee), the small feed launcher is the pistol, the large feed launcher is the machine gun, and the Super Feeder 5000 is the chaingun. What sets this game apart from Wolf3D is that it has two additional weapons: the cantaloupe feeder and the watermelon feeder. Both of these weapons use alternate ammo from the other weapons and actually deal some splash damage. The cantaloupe feeder fires two rounds in sequence which makes it a decent strafing weapon and the watermelon feeder is great for quickly taking down tough enemies.

-Music-
It loops quite a bit and isn’t very impressive. It maintains the light-hearted theme of the game and the boss level theme isn’t too bad. Not much else to say about it otherwise.

-Levels/Difficulty-
Since this game is geared more towards kids, it is understandably easier than Wolfenstein. Secrets are also more identifiable (at least for me they were) and the game generally leaves more pickups laying around for both ammo and health. The game even features scrolls which pose a trivia question about Noah’s ark and reward the player with health. As far as the level design goes, I think the game does a very good job. Some of the earlier levels feel longer than the early Wolf3D levels but the game is considerably shorter than Wolf3D. What really impressed me are the boss fights. At the start of each chapter you are told what animal you will need to put to sleep. The fights themselves have very well designed stages around them. They have plenty of room to fight, spots to hide when things get dicey, additional enemies to distract you/add more challenge, and side rooms to run away from the boss. These fights are surprisingly robust in comparison to Wolf3D’s bosses. So even though most enemies don’t take too much to dispatch, they can sneak up on you and take you out very quick if you are not careful.

-Final Conclusion-
The game is good. Get it if you enjoy Wolfenstein 3D and want to see better bosses and more weapons. Don’t get if you don’t like the light-hearted theme or dislike the looping music.

reviewText:
This is not a review of Super 3-D Noah's Ark. Instead, it's a juxtoposition of Id/Bethesda's attitude to their classic games on Steam and Piko/WisdomTree/ECWolf. Put frankly, Id and Bethesda don't care about their older properties. Classic Id games like Doom and Wolfenstein 3D have terrible terrible Steam versions not even on par with some console ports. The Steam ports of both are as phoned in as possible, clearly put up just to have them listed on Steam. To make matters worse, they were the first studio to get away with this. Back when there was very little on Steam but Bethesda and Valve properties, Id set the standard for bad ports with these games.

Some background for the unfamiliar, Id Software's engines are among the most free and meticulously documented engines in mainstream gaming. Id, from the beginning, has consistently released the source code to its engines a few years after it stopped making games with each of them. What this means, is that both the Doom and Wolfenstein 3D engines are available as source code, allowing gamers to create versions of the engines that support new platforms, are more stable, and allowing for new features. So this seems like an easy fix right? Go to github, grab the latest stable build of ECWolf or GZDoom and plugin the proprietary files. You end up with a version of both games that runs on Windows, OSX, Linux, iPhone, Android, PSP, DS, PS3, PS2, Xbox 360, Xbox et al.

Bethesda and Id didn't do this. They simply released 20 year old windows executables with no patches or bugfixes. These versions are known to be problematic on modern windows, so .bat files and dosbox are also included, which run an even older version of the game. Whatever version you run, it won't support your resolution or graphics card, I hope you enjoy playing these games without a mouse, in software mode, at a crippled or overly sped up framerate, at 480p 4:3, stretched to 16:9 with no way to unstretch it other than changing your monitor settings. No DirectX. No OpenGL. These games don't even know if you have a GPU or not.

And then you have Wisdom Tree, the ECWolf devs, and Piko Interactive. Through a licensing collaboration, advanced Noah's Ark specific features were backported to ECWolf by hand. Thanks to relying on the ECWolf source port, the game supports modern hardware, comes defaulted with controls that make sense, supports OpenGL, runs on OSX and Linux, consistently hits 60fps, and runs and looks like butter. Best of all, all of this works without ruining the artstyle or menus of the original game. This is a brillaint port job, and makes Id and Bethesda look like elitist hacks who hate their communities.

The only reason I can think of for Bethesda's arrogance is toxic proprietary software elitism. Put simply, Bethesda doesn't respect the work that Id has done on these free engines, nor the work by the community, and thinks their terrible dosbox ports better because they aren't maintained by hobbyists. This is a disgusting outdated view, even Microsoft doesn't operate this way anymore, leaving only the games industry to wallow in greed and judgement of its own customers. Worst of all, buying these games on steam is about the only legal way to get the data files needed to run them in a modern engine, so Doom fans will continue to buy them to support Id. This is depressing and unethical, and bethesda should really do something to fix it. My advice is that if you buy them, make sure to leave a negative review.

Bravo to Wisdom Tree though for their honesty and open-minded attitude towards Source Ports, though I guess I shouldn't be surprised, Wisdom Tree has been protesting lockouts and licensing for decades.

reviewText:
While it's not the worst game out there, it's still not very good and here's why.

Anyone who has any knowledge of the Bible know Noah and his Ark. For those who don't know. Noah builds an Ark tor the great flood and puts two of each animal inside the ark.

The game is set inside the ark and your goal is to go around the multiple floors of the ark and find the animals and put them to sleep so they stop causing trouble.

The game has a rich back story of being one of the most infamous SNES games of all time. Originally Hellraiser the video game it was reworked into this game, with the bible theme around it and was brought into the mainstream by AVGN who made a video on this game.

The game is nothing more than a Wolfenstein clone and nothing more. You go around a maze like environment, look for keys and go to the next floor. The gameplay is also identical.

The game is a first person shooter, where you use a slingshot to shoot food into the animals to make them fall asleep.
Later on you can pick up different types of slingshots, but all that changes is the fire rate. Also you can pick up melon launchers, but those are incredibly useless and you will only use them in dire situations.

The graphics are alright for the most part. Everything looks crisp as it is updated from the original graphics which is nice, but the level layouts almost always look the same which brings me to my next point.

The level design is atrocious. Now don't get me wrong Wolfenstein had a lot of this as well, but the way this game does this maze like environment is atrocious. The map doesn't help at all and is pretty much useless in the end. The graphics make everything look the same making it hard to figure out where you've been and where you haven't been.

The soundtrack is atrocious and it's just best to mute the entire game and to listen to something else while playing.

The game counter told me it took me 2 hours to finish and that with a lot of trial and error. A lot of the later stages have massive difficulty spikes which make you be as careful as possible.

Final Thoughts:
Super 3D Noah's Ark is a mediocre Wolfenstein rip off. It's been called the worst clone out there, but after playing it, I have to disagree. While the game is not good, it's definitely not the worst clone out there when stuff like Nerves of Steel exist.

Cons:

- Terrible Audio

reviewText:
Super 3-D Noah's Ark. Now if that isn't a title that sells itself, I don't know what is.

S3DNA is a Wolfenstein 3D clone, and before I say anything more, I feel like I should start with: it's actually not bad. In fact, it's pretty decent. If you like Wolfenstein 3D, that is. And I do! Very much.

All the animals on the ark have grown roudy. As Noah, it's up to you to feed them all (or as many as you have to until you've beaten the six bosses, anyways) so that they'll go to sleep. In order to streamline this process, you'll be shooting the feed at their faces using various slingshots and what-have-you. Basically, what we have here, is a kid-friendly Wolfenstein 3D.

Now, you've probably mostly all seen the Angry Video Game Nerd's review of the original Super Nintendo game. The one that came in a jank bootleg cartridge that required you to plug another game into the top of it because Nintendo never gave the game their approval. If you haven't, here you go: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LkNvQYiM6bw (skip to 13:17 for S3DNA). What you've seen or will see there is a low-resolution, low-framerate game which doesn't really look like a lot of fun.

The Steam version is not a straight port.

This baby has been given a nice spitshine for its new release. It seems that, rather than the original company bringing it over, a fan actually sought and received permission to put this port together and release it for us. The game looks good! I mean, well. It looks like a Wolfenstein 3D clone. And, being on a wooden ship, the environments are mostly brown, though there are more colorful areas here and there. But it looks about as good as all that could look.

The game runs smoothly, and it seems some work has been put into making it acceptable for PC gamers. There are loads of options which I'm certain wouldn't have been in the original. Controls, audio... I wasn't even expecting display options, but they're there. There are seven options for the automap.

The level design is also surprisingly competent! The narrow, twisty mazes got annoying towards the middle, but overall it's decent classic shooter fare for anyone who finished Wolf3D and Spear of Destiny and want more, but don't want all the fancy big city modern complications of Doom or Duke Nukem 3D. Or for those people who want a shooter, but also want to answer questions about the Bible and aren't allowed to play anything violent!

This Steam release is even better, as the source port it uses adds a lot of stuff too, like hi-res, widescreen, smaller weapon sprites, level stats on the map screen, and such. Plus it fixes the music bug that plagued the original version. Sounds great, and consistent.

Don't believe the bad hype. If you like Wolf3D due to the gore and Nazis, then yeah, you'll be disappointed. But if you enjoy Wolf3D for the gameplay and challenge, then you'll love this game.

Even though the rumours were nothing more than urban legend, I still was interested in seeing this oddity for myself.

If you can get past the odd aesthetics of the game, then you might as well give it a try, considering that the dev who ported this oddity is the developer for ECWolf, a great source port of Wolfenstein 3D, (which this game happens to run on) as well as a developer for ZDoom. I don't mind throwing a few bucks to support Blzut3, considering his work on ECWolf and ZDoom, both of which are great source ports.

If you are concerned about the religious theme of the game, don't worry, it's pretty much just windowdressing. I'm an Atheist, and the game doesnt bother me. It's not trying to push an agenda or anything, it's just Wolfenstein 3D where you go around shooting nazi animals. The game was pretty much created to sell FPS games to overprotective parents. I view it as a novelty game, and nothing more than an odd modification of Wolf3D.

Now new people who are looking at this game, listen to me well and listen to me now DONOT BUY THIS SACK OF GOD'S ♥♥♥♥. GOD HIMSELF ♥♥♥♥ ON THE SNES FROM THE HEAVENS AND NOW HE DECIDED TO DO IT AGAIN TO PC IN 2015! GOD HIMSELF WOULDN'T HAVE MERCY ON THIS GAME'S OR THE DEVELOPERS SOULS!

I'll give u a bit of background on this game. Super 3D Noah's Ark was one of many bible games released by wisdom tree in the early 90s. They were primarily released for nes, however those games were later ported for sega genesis. This was the last game made by wisdom tree and it's probably their most shameless one. Their other games were sh*t but this one takes the sh**ting crown. At least their other games weren't a rip off of another game. That's right Super 3D Noah's ark is  a rip off of Wolfenstein 3D. But they have one difference, Wolfenstein 3D was good.

Ill now talk about how bad Noah's ark is.  You play as Noah carrying a slingshot and you need to shoot food at animals that are currently in the ark in order for them to suddenly fall asleep straight after and for some weird reason these animals are really angry with Noah because all of them are attacking him.... I couldn't make this up. What did Noah do to these animals to make them all so mad with him. He saved their lives by putting them on the ark. Also, I'm not religious or anything like that but I know for a fact that Noah only put 2 of every animalon the ark so why are there like 100 goats, sheep, ostriches,oxes and probably every other animal on the ark? FOR A RELIGIOUS VIDEO GAME COMPANY THEY DON'T REALLY KNOW THAT MUCH ABOUT RELIGION!

There are also questions about the bible in the game basically it's multiple choice, it gives you the question and gives you the passage. If u get the question correct u get an extra 5 health and 5 ammo no sorry it isn't called ammo it's called feed. One thing I noticed is that one one of the questions, I noticed it didn't give me a passage it instead said No hint!" THE PASSAGES WERE HINTS!? DO THE DEVELOPERS OF THE GAME SERIOUSLY THINK THAT I HAVE A BIBLE NXT TO ME WHEN I PLAY MY GAMES?! WHEN I PLAY SKYRIM I DON'T CARRY A BIBLE AROUND AND GIVE EVRY ENEMY IN THE GAME A FUNERAL WHEN IKILL THEM!

The best way to sum up Super 3D Noah's Ark is one word "Weird" I fail to see why wisdom tree thught that this game would be  a good idea. Also this game wasn't officially released on the snes

This is a weird game with no sense to it at all and I'm still trying to figure outa meaning behind this game and I'm sure religions will find the meaning of life before I find that answer
